title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions for disparities in polling place availability. The Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents to be used for voting purposes. The Attorney General can take action against disparities in voting opportunities for members of Indian tribes. This includes increasing the availability of polling places. The Voting Rights Act is amended to address disparities in voting opportunities, allowing tribal ID for voting. District courts have jurisdiction over actions related to voting rights disparities, with a presumption of denial of voting rights based on race or color. An aggrieved person can bring an action under certain provisions. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include protections for Indian reservations, requiring approval for certain activities like eliminating polling places or voter registration sites, moving them further away, or making travel difficult for voters on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions like eliminating polling places or reducing early voting opportunities on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions like changing voting procedures. SEC. 4 amends the Voting Rights Act to allow Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if a complaint is received about potential voter rights violations. SEC. 5 addresses the termination of election observers. SEC. 5 amends the Voting Rights Act to specify the termination of election observers appointed under subsection (b) of section 8 after the next general election for President. SEC. 6 amends the Voting Rights Act to define terms related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations. SEC. 7 updates bilingual election requirements and the definition of Indian reservation. The Attorney General must release reports of Federal election observers within 6 months. Additionally, the Attorney General should consult with tribal organizations annually on voting issues for Indian tribe members.
